awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Molecular Understanding and Catalyst Design for the Direct Synthesis of H2O2
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract (Flaherty; 1553137)

Currently millions of tons of hazardous chlorinated compounds are used for selective oxidation and bleaching reactions in the manufacture of pulp, paper, and commodity chemicals each year.  Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) represents a "green" alternative to chlorinated compounds, but it is not widely used because the current production method is economically viable only at very large scales.  The proposed study will investigate an alternative catalytic approach - direct synthesis of H2O2 from hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) gases - that would enable H2O2 production on-site for use in smaller, more common processing facilities.   The proposed research is integrated with educational programs focusing on young women with emphasis on building research and research-mentoring skills.

The research will combine catalytic kinetic and in situ spectroscopic measurements in a systematic investigation to determine: 1) the mechanism for direct synthesis of H2O2, 2) the roles of surfaces, solvents, and liquid-phase intermediates in forming reactive intermediates, and 3) the combined effects of catalyst composition and solvent properties on reaction rates and selectivities.  The initial work will focus on palladium (Pd) and palladium-gold (PdAu) clusters as the active catalytic materials, but learning derived from those materials will be used to generate guiding principles and activity descriptors to identify inexpensive alternatives to PdAu catalysts.  To achieve these goals, a combination of kinetic and (ex situ and in situ) infrared spectroscopic techniques will be employed to probe the catalytic chemistry at the liquid-solid interfaces of supported metal clusters.  This investigation will involve design parameters such as: size and composition of the metal clusters, the role of electrophilic adsorbates, and solvent properties such as pH and polarity.  Although these studies specifically target the direct synthesis of H2O2, the work will develop tools and expertise needed for future investigations of a broad range of oxidative and reductive chemistries at liquid-solid interfaces.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Our research sought to develop fundamental understanding of the mechanism for the direct synthesis of H2O2 (H2+O2→H2O2) and principles to design improved catalysts and processes.  Knowledge we developed will advance technologies to produce H2O2, which is an environmentally preferred alternative to hazardous chlorinated compounds now used for industrial oxidations and bleaching (at a scale of millions of tons per year). We created, characterized, and examined new forms of catalysts including metal nanoparticles, alloy nanoparticles, and organically modified nanoparticle catalysts. Our work revealed the molecular basis and requirements to create H2O2 selectively and to suppress undesired side reactions.  We revealed unrecognized chemical phenomena of redox mediators at nanoparticle surfaces (Figure 1); identified fundamental links between electrocatalysis and thermocatalysis; developed new strategies to synthesize and characterize alloy nanoparticle catalysts; and demonstrated techniques to examine the restructuring of these surfaces during reactions.

This work was critical not only for expanding fundamental scientific knowledge of chemistry at solid-liquid interfaces but also to establish technologies to manufacture H2O2 in small, on-site facilities and at costs much lower than what we have today.  Use of H2O2 would become much more economical, and consequently, this would help to reduce the current quantity of chlorine-based oxidants used in the pulp, paper, and chemical industries (63?109 kg each year).  In turn, these changes can decrease the amount of dioxins and other contaminants in effluent streams. This research will provide accurate, molecular descriptions of how H2O2 forms at active sites of metal clusters catalysts with uniform sizes and compositions. Our work provided guiding principles and reactivity and selectivity descriptors for the design of bimetallic catalysts for the direct synthesis of H2O2 and for aqueous oxidations involving related chemical intermediates. As one key example, the findings from our research into precious metal nanoparticles demonstrated how slight differences in the arrangement of metal atoms upon nanoparticle surfaces influence rates to form the desired product (hydrogen peroxide) and the undesired product (water) very differently (Figure 2).

Through the research activities financially supported by this grant, multiple graduate (6) and undergraduate students (>10) were trained in current methods for the synthesis, characterization, testing, and kinetic analysis of solid catalyst that are relevant for the U.S. energy and chemical sectors. The expertise and knowledge developed by these participants was shared with the broader chemical engineering and catalysis community through 14 publications to date and more than 70 presentations at technical meetings and universities. These students have moved on to rewarding independent careers as energy researchers in industry and as teachers in universities. Their training will continue to have a positive impact over the next several decades. By engaging with summer programs at the University of Illinois, our team educated more than one hundred high school women (grades 9 - 12) with classroom and hands-on experiments that taught key principles of catalysis and its role in energy conversion and environmental protection for our society.

 


Last Modified: 07/25/2022
Modified by: David Flaherty
